action.action-desc: Mr. Mrvan introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Veterans' Affairs

form.official-title: To amend title 38, United States Code, to improve hearings before the Board of Veterans’ Appeals regarding claims involving military sexual trauma.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Dignity for MST Survivors Act.

section.header: Requirement for training on claims involving military sexual trauma prior to assignment of certain proceedings

subsection.text: Section 7102 of title 38, United States Code, is amended by adding at the end the following new subsection:

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall ensure that there is offered to each member of the Board an annual training on military sexual trauma and proceedings that concern a claim for compensation based on military sexual trauma experienced by a veteran.

A proceeding that concerns a claim specified in paragraph (1) may not be assigned to an individual member of the Board or to a panel of members unless the individual member, or each member of the panel, as the case may be, has completed the annual training most recently offered to that member pursuant to such paragraph.
In this subsection, the term military sexual trauma has the meaning given that term in section 1166(c) of this title.

subsection.text: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall ensure that each member of the Board of Veterans’ Appeals is offered the first annual training under section 7102(c) of title 38, United States Code, as amended by subsection (a), by not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.

The limitation under section 7102(c)(2) of title 38, United States Code, as added by subsection (a), shall apply with respect to the assignment of proceedings on or after the date that is 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act.

section.header: Review of language and practices used in connection with claims involving military sexual trauma

paragraph.text: Section 7112 of title 38, United States Code, is amended—

subparagraph.text: by inserting (a) Remanded claims.— before The Secretary; and
by adding at the end the following new subsections:

subsection.text: The Board shall promptly determine whether a notice of disagreement filed with the Board is a covered case.

paragraph.text: The term covered case means a case—

subparagraph.text: that concerns a claim for compensation based on military sexual trauma; and
for which the appellant has requested a hearing in the notice of disagreement filed with the Board pursuant to section 7105 of this title.

paragraph.text: The term military sexual trauma has the meaning given that term in section 1166 of this title.

subparagraph.text: The heading of such section is amended by striking remanded and inserting certain.
The table of sections at the beginning of chapter 71 of such title is amended by striking the item relating to section 7112 and inserting the following:

subsection.header: Audit and modification of denial letters

paragraph.text: The Secretary of Veterans Affairs shall conduct an audit of the language used in letters sent to individuals to explain the decision by the Secretary to deny covered claims. Not later than 180 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary shall modify the letters to ensure that—

subparagraph.text: the letters use trauma-informed language; and
veterans are not re-traumatized through insensitive language.

paragraph.text: The Secretary shall carry out paragraph (1) in consultation with veterans service organizations and other stakeholders as the Secretary determines appropriate.

subsection.text: The Secretary shall establish protocols for contract medical providers to ensure that the medical providers conduct examinations regarding covered claims using trauma-informed practices.

paragraph.text: The term compensation has the meaning given that term in section 101 of title 38, United States Code.

The term contract medical provider means a medical provider who contracts with the Department of Veterans Affairs to provide a medical examination or a medical opinion when such an examination or opinion is necessary to make a decision on a claim under the laws administered by the Secretary of Veterans Affairs.
The term covered claim means a claim for compensation based on military sexual trauma experienced by a veteran.
The term military sexual trauma has the meaning given that term in section 1166 of title 38, United States Code.
The term trauma-informed means, with respect to language or practices, using language or carrying out practices in a manner that—

subparagraph.text: is based on a knowledge of the awareness of the prevalence and impact of trauma on the physical, emotional, and mental health of an individual, the behaviors of the individual, and the engagement by the individual to services;
is aimed at ensuring environments and services are welcoming and engaging to the individual who receives such services and the staff who provide such services; and
ensures that the language or practices do not retraumatize the individual.
